channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Leaving the Land: New China Cities: Shoddy Homes, Broken Hope
item.description: China’s government-led urbanization, meant to solve one problem, may be creating a new set of troubles that could plague Chinese cities for generations.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Syrian Rebels Said to Recapture Base
item.description: Syrian rebels recaptured a base near the international airport in the northern city of Aleppo in a counteroffensive hours after the Syrian Army had advanced into the area, activists said on Saturday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Red Cross Fears 1,200 Deaths in Philippine Typhoon
item.description: The typhoon that ripped through the country on Friday inundated isolated villages on the islands of Leyte and Samar, officials said, with a body count yet to be determined.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Talks for Iran Nuclear Deal End Without Agreement
item.description: After optimistic reports that negotiations with Iran were on track to produce the first agreement in a decade to freeze its nuclear program, the talks ended without one, the French foreign minister said.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with the European Union's high representative for foreign affairs, Catherine Ashton, center, and the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, right, on Saturday in Geneva.

item.title: Manfred Rommel, Son of German Field Marshal, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Rommel, a three-term mayor of Stuttgart, was a liberal voice in postwar West Germany, supporting immigrant rights and strengthening the city’s Jewish population.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Former President Leads in Maldives Election as Candidates Head to Runoff
item.description: Former President Mohamed Nasheed won the most votes but did not break the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid a second round.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A woman cast her vote on Saturday in Male, Maldives. If no candidate receives 50 percent of the votes, a runoff will be held on Sunday.

item.title: The Lede: Eyewitness Reports After Typhoon in Philippines
item.description: Video and photos show the extent of the damage after powerful Typhoon Haiyan tore through the center of the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Bangladesh Arrests Opposition Figures
item.description: Three senior leaders of the main opposition party were arrested as a nationwide strike was announced.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Reporter for Reuters Won’t Receive China Visa
item.description: The rejection comes amid rising tensions between foreign news organizations and the Chinese government, which has been using various means to express displeasure with coverage it deems unflattering.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Portrait of Deng as Reformer in 1978 Plenum Ignores History
item.description: The conventional account of how the 1978 Third Plenum transformed Chinais a compound of selective memories, and a deceptive guide to how the country’s steps to economic transformation really happened.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Deadly Blast Hits Hotel in Somalia
item.description: Witnesses and officials said at least four people were killed and scores wounded in a bombing outside an expensive hotel in Mogadishu.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Bloomberg News Is Said to Curb Articles That Might Anger China
item.description: Employees said Bloomberg News chose not to publish investigative articles about China’s leadership because of worries that it would be evicted from the country.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: The Lede: Netanyahu Deplores Potential ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, made his disapproval of a potential agreement over Iran’s nuclear program clear both before and after meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: A Powerful Typhoon Speeds Across the Philippines
item.description: The storm, named Haiyan, killed at least 100 people and forced the evacuation of hundreds of thousands.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: High waves amid strong winds pounded the coast on Friday as a typhoon hit the city of Legaspi. At least four died, officials said.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Animated Take on Bloomberg’s Coverage of China
item.description: A debate within Bloomberg News over how to handle coverage of China provokes an animated depiction of the situation.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Roadblocks Remain as Officials Work Toward Iranian Nuclear Pact
item.description: Among the most contentious issues during the talks in Geneva have been the fate of a reactor in Iran, the country’s stockpile of uranium and how much relief to give it from punishing sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran, center, in Geneva on Friday after a meeting with Western officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry.

item.title: Before Global Games, Rio Is Fighting to Dim Red Light
item.description: A racy metropolis is razing slums and shuttering red-light emporiums, but the campaign isn’t easy.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside Centaurus, a well-traveled brothel in the Ipanema neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro. A number of notable people have been caught in the glare there.

item.title: On Iran, Netanyahu Can Only Fume
item.description: The prime minister’s hard-line stance against a deal with Tehran reflects a widening gulf between Israel and the United States on issues in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after a meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday. Mr. Netanyahu condemned a possible deal to ease sanctions against Iran.

item.title: Politically Adrift, Algeria Clings to Its Old Ways
item.description: A range of problems, from a prostrate economy to declining levels of education, have been left to fester and now threaten to undermine the country’s future and even eventual stability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children in the Casbah neighborhood of Algiers, where Algerian forces hid during the war of independence from France.

item.title: Right Wing’s Surge in Europe Has the Establishment Rattled
item.description: All over Europe, established political forces are losing ground to grass-roots insurgents fired by resentment against a governing class many see as out of touch.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Laerke Posselt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mikkel Dencker, a mayoral candidate in Hvidovre, Denmark, put up campaign posters. He has made the removal of meatballs from kindergarten in deference to Islam a campaign issue.

item.title: CBS to Correct Erroneous Report on Benghazi
item.description: The network acknowledged that it had suffered a blow to its credibility in broadcasting a report with an interview of someone who was never at the scene.
item.dc:creator: By BILL CARTER and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Lara Logan acknowledged the “mistake” on Friday.

item.title: With Survey, Vatican Seeks Laity Comment on Family Issues
item.description: In a questionnaire being distributed to bishops in advance of their synod next fall, Pope Francis is asking Catholics for their thoughts and opinions on contentious social issues.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis at his weekly general audience on Wednesday in St. Peter’s Square. The Vatican has sent parishes a questionnaire before a 2014 synod.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: U.S. Reporter Detained
item.description: The Miami Herald’s Jim Wyss was picked up Thursday near the country’s western border with Colombia, according to an article on the newspaper’s website.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Violence Increases Hunger Risk, U.N. Warns
item.description: The World Food Program of the United Nations said in a statement that 1.1 million people are at risk of hunger and that their plight could worsen.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Video: The Fate of Egypt’s Jon Stewart
item.description: A popular satirist, Bassem Youssef, was taken off the air after he made jokes about Egypt’s military leaders, triggering a debate on the military’s commitment to democracy.
item.dc:creator: By WILL STOREY and MONA EL-NAGGAR
